data.title: All 110 David Strathairn Movies (in Order)
data.meta_description: Get ready to dive into the world of David Strathairn as we take you on a journey through his remarkable filmography. From classic roles to critically acclaimed performances, we’ve compiled a list of…
data.text:
Lauren Ross

·

Follow

41 min read

·

Mar 17, 2024

--

Get ready to dive into the world of David Strathairn as we take you on a journey through his remarkable filmography. From classic roles to critically acclaimed performances, we’ve compiled a list of must-watch movies starring this talented actor. So sit back, grab your popcorn, and let’s explore the fascinating world of David Strathairn Movies.

1. Return of the Secaucus Seven (1980)

Return of the Secaucus Seven is a heartfelt drama directed by John Sayles, released in 1980. The film revolves around seven former college friends, played by Bruce MacDonald, Maggie Renzi, and Adam LeFevre, who reunite at a summer house in New Hampshire. As they reminisce about their past, they recall a memorable protest in Washington, DC, where they were arrested.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

2. Enormous Changes at the Last Minute (1983)

Enormous Changes at the Last Minute is a 1983 American drama film that is composed of three distinct segments, all of which share a common thematic thread. The film explores the lives of three different women, as they navigate through unexpected changes in their relationships, personal lives, and familial ties.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

3. Lovesick (1983)

Lovesick is a quirky 1983 movie that combines comedy, fantasy, and romance. Directed by Marshall Brickman, the film stars Dudley Moore, Elizabeth McGovern, and Alec Guinness. The plot revolves around a psychiatrist who falls in love with one of his patients and is visited by the spirit of Sigmund Freud, providing him advice on handling the situation.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

4. Silkwood (1983)

Silkwood” is a gripping and historically significant drama from 1983, directed by Mike Nichols and written by Nora Ephron and Alice Arlen. Meryl Streep, Kurt Russell, and Cher star in this intense tale, set in the nuclear industry during the Cold War era.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

5. Iceman (1984)

In the thrilling 1984 movie “Iceman, “ a prehistoric Neanderthal man, frozen in ice, is miraculously brought back to life by an ambitious arctic exploration team. Fueled by their desire for scientific discovery, the team attempts to exploit the man’s unique capabilities for their own benefit. As the Neanderthal struggles to adapt to modern life, he forms an unexpected bond with the team and must confront the moral dilemma of his newfound existence.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

6. The Brother from Another Planet (1984)

In the 1984 film, “The Brother from Another Planet, “ a mute alien with the appearance of a black human is pursued by outer-space bounty hunters through the bustling streets of Harlem, New York City. This unique and captivating sci-fi comedy, directed by John Sayles, tells the tale of a humble alien seeking freedom and connection in the heart of a diverse city.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

7. When Nature Calls (1985)

When Nature Calls, “ released in 1985, is a comedy film that follows construction worker Greg, who feels trapped by his job and city life. Tired of his unruly foreman and the urban chaos, Greg decides to escape with his wife and kids to a serene, rural setting. As they navigate the wilderness, the family encounters unexpected challenges and hilarious mishaps in this heartwarming film that showcases the beauty of nature and the importance of family bonds.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

8. At Close Range (1986)

At Close Range is a gripping crime drama released in 1986, starring Sean Penn, Christopher Walken, and Mary Stuart Masterson. Directed by James Foley, the movie showcases the dangerous journey of a tough teen named Brad, who becomes reunited with his career criminal father.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

9. Broken Vows (1987)

Broken Vows, “ set in 1987, is a gripping drama that follows a ghetto priest as he grapples with his calling and embarks on a mission to uncover the truth behind a brutal murder. After providing the final rites to a deceased man, the priest finds a renewed sense of purpose, determined to help the victim’s heartbroken girlfriend avenge his death.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

10. Matewan (1987)

In the early 1920s, coal mining company Matewan (1987) tells the gripping story of a community’s struggle for justice and rights against a powerful, brutal corporation. John Sayles directs and writes an epic tale of the mining town of Matewan, West Virginia, where the company ruthlessly enforces its dominance and control over the workers. Enter Joe Kenehan (Chris Cooper), a dedicated labor union organizer, who arrives in the small town to represent the interests of the exploited miners.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

11. Call Me (1988)

Call Me, “ released in 1989, is a chilling drama-thriller directed by Sollace Mitchell and written by Karyn Kay and Sollace Mitchell. The film stars Patricia Charbonneau, Stephen McHattie, and Boyd Gaines in pivotal roles.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

12. Eight Men Out (1988)

In 1988, the film “Eight Men Out” delves into the dark world of match fixing and corruption, based on the true story of the Black Sox scandal. The Chicago White Sox, underpaid and desperate, accepted bribes to lose the 1919 World Series.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

13. Dominick and Eugene (1988)

Dominick and Eugene is a captivating drama film that follows the relationship between two brothers, Dominick and Eugene. The story begins with Dominick, who is a little slower due to an accident, and his twin brother, Eugene, who dreams of becoming a doctor. They both live together, with Dominick working as a garbage man to support Eugene’s medical education.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

14. Stars and Bars (1988)

Stars and Bars” (1988) is a charming comedy that follows a British art expert on a business trip across America in pursuit of a rare Renoir painting. As he travels through the South, he encounters an array of quirky characters and finds himself embroiled in unexpected situations.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

15. Day One (1989)

Day One”, a moving 1989 miniseries, delves into the tumultuous events surrounding the use of the atomic bomb in ending World War II. This gripping drama, which earned an Emmy for its compelling performances, provides an intimate exploration of the emotional turmoil faced by its characters, portrayed by an esteemed ensemble of actors. The story sheds light on the controversial choices and consequences of the atomic bomb’s creation and its impact on the world post-World War II.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

16. The Feud (1989)

In The Feud, a seemingly harmless incident of a cigar-smoking customer, Dolf Beeler, disregarding the no-smoking policy at Bud Bullard’s hardware store ignites a fire that fuels an extreme feud between the two families. While the majority of the family members from both sides relish in their dislike for one another, some members recognize the absurdity of the ongoing conflict. This intriguing dark comedy explores the complexities of family relationships and the sometimes irrational nature of rivalries, set amidst the backdrop of a quaint small town.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

17. Memphis Belle (1990)

Memphis Belle, “ released in 1990, is an enthralling war drama that takes viewers on a poignant journey through the final days of World War II. Set in 1943, the story follows the dedicated crew of a B-17 bomber stationed in the UK, as they prepare for their 25th and final mission over Germany. The film immerses the audience in the camaraderie, danger, and emotional turmoil faced by a group of young airmen far from home.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

18. Judgment (1990)

Judgment” is a gripping drama portraying the real-life events that unfolded in the early 1990s. A Louisiana priest is accused of molesting young parishioners, leaving a once-happy congregation in turmoil. As the family of one of the victims grapples with the horrifying revelations, they struggle to find their way between their unwavering loyalty to their son and the sanctity of their church.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

19. Heat Wave (1990)

Heat Wave” is a gripping drama film that delves into the historical events of the 1965 race riots in Watts, Los Angeles. The narrative unfolds through the perspective of a black messenger-turned-reporter who arrives at the scene, becoming one of the first correspondents on the ground. As the film probes the tensions and challenges faced by the reporter and his loved ones, it shines a light on the heart-wrenching and poignant period of American history.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

20. Without Warning: The James Brady Story (1991)

Without Warning: The James Brady Story” is a powerful drama based on a true event that unfolded in the 1980s. The film revolves around James Brady, a press secretary to Ronald Reagan, who was gravely injured during an assassination attempt on the president’s life. John Hinckley Jr.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

21. Big Girls Don’t Cry… They Get Even (1991)

Big Girls Don’t Cry. . They Get Even” is a quirky and heartwarming comedy from 1991 that follows the tale of a 13-year-old girl fleeing her dysfunctional family. The film, released in 1992, weaves a story of family bonding and self-discovery as the family members seek to understand themselves and each other. With a runtime of just 1 hour and 36 minutes, the film has gained a cult following and an IMDb rating of 6.3 based on 2,076 votes.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

22. City of Hope (1991)

In the vibrant town of New Haven, the City of Hope shines as the hub of life for its diverse community. The community is set in motion when a construction company, Hellman Development, announces the demolition of an old apartment building named the “City of Hope. “ As the city braces for change, the tale unfolds through intersecting lives of the residents, portraying a vivid social commentary on hope, resilience, and the human spirit.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

23. O Pioneers! (1992)

Experience a captivating tale of love, loss, and resilience with “O Pioneers! “ (1992), a heartwarming drama based on Willa Cather’s renowned novel. Directed by Glenn Jordan and starring Jessica Lange, David Strathairn, and Tom Aldredge, this touching film brings to life the story of Alexandra Bergson, a young woman who inherits the family farm and must forge her own path amidst the windswept prairie.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

24. A League of Their Own (1992)

A League of Their Own is an entertaining tale that follows the journeys of two sisters who join the first female professional baseball league during a time when women’s sports were still striving for recognition. As they struggle to keep their fledgling league afloat, their own growing rivalry adds another layer of drama to their unfolding story.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

25. Sneakers (1992)

Sneakers” is a charming comedy-drama film that premiered in 1992. Directed by Phil Alden Robinson, this engaging movie features an incredible star-studded cast including Robert Redford, Dan Aykroyd, and Sidney Poitier. The plot revolves around a security professional who, along with his unique team, is assigned a mission to retrieve a vital item. As the protagonist grapples with his past, he encounters various challenges that test the skills and loyalty of his team.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

26. Passion Fish (1992)

In “Passion Fish, “ we’re introduced to Chantelle, a former soap opera star who has faced a tragic accident, becoming paraplegic. This life-altering event sends her on a journey to recover both mentally and emotionally. As she fights to regain her footing in life, she meets her newest nurse, Lillian, who is also struggling in her own way.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

27. Bob Roberts (1992)

Bob Roberts” (1992) is a comedic political satire that explores the shady world of election campaigns. Tim Robbins plays the titular character, a conservative folk singer who turns his hand to politics, running for the US Senate. Robbins’ character is not above using underhanded tactics and smear campaigns to gain an advantage over his opponent, making for an entertaining and unpredictable ride.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

28. Lost in Yonkers (1993)

Lost in Yonkers” is a heartwarming and comedic drama film from 1993, directed by Martha Coolidge and written by Neil Simon. Set in the summer of 1942, two young boys, Jerry and Arty, are sent from their chaotic home in Brooklyn to live with their stern grandmother and lovable aunt in Yonkers, New York. As Jerry and Arty navigate the trials and tribulations of growing up in this new environment, they find solace in their aunt’s kindness and a newfound love for life.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

29. The American Clock (1993)

The American Clock” is a profound and moving drama film released in 1993, directed by Bob Clark and written by Arthur Miller and Frank Galati. Based on the 1930s economic depression, the story unfolds as an upper-class family, represented by John Rubinstein, Mary McDonnell, and Loren Dean, experiences the devastating consequences of the Stock Market crash.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

30. A Dangerous Woman (1993)

In the gripping drama “A Dangerous Woman, “ Martha Horgan, a bright yet sheltered woman with an intellectual impairment, lives with her aunt Frances in a small town. Known for telling the truth, even in the most difficult situations, she embarks on a journey of self-discovery and forms unexpected bonds.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

31. The Firm (1993)

The Firm (1993) is a gripping drama, mystery, and thriller film that takes viewers on a captivating journey into the dark underbelly of a prestigious law firm. The film tells the story of a young, ambitious lawyer who joins the prestigious firm, only to uncover its sinister dark side. The director Sydney Pollack weaves a tense narrative, where the protagonist must navigate a maze of conspiracy, seduction, and danger.

32. The River Wild (1994)

The River Wild” is a thrilling adventure that takes viewers on a heart-pounding rafting trip gone wrong. When expert rafter Gail (Meryl Streep) and her estranged husband Tom (Kevin Bacon) embark on a family vacation, they must navigate a dangerous, unpredictable river filled with treacherous obstacles and unseen threats. Little do they know, the peaceful vacation quickly becomes a deadly game of survival, as they find themselves engaged in a deadly confrontation with a ruthless gang of violent criminals led by a mysterious figure.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

33. Dolores Claiborne (1995)

Dolores Claiborne, a gripping crime drama, sees a big-city reporter embarking on a chilling investigation when her mother is arrested for the murder of an elderly woman she once worked for as a housekeeper. As twists and turns begin to unravel, the film tackles themes of abuse, pedophilia, and childhood trauma.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

34. Losing Isaiah (1995)

Losing Isaiah” is a heart-wrenching drama from 1995, starring Jessica Lange, Halle Berry, and David Strathairn. The film chronicles the harrowing custody battle between the biological and adoptive mothers of a young boy, Isaiah.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

35. Home for the Holidays (1995)

Home for the Holidays, “ a delightful 1995 comedy-drama film, follows Claudia Larson (played by Holly Hunter) as she faces a series of unfortunate events leading up to Thanksgiving. After losing her job and making out with her soon-to-be ex-boss, she learns that her daughter plans to spend the holiday with her boyfriend instead of the family. Faced with a tough decision, Claudia decides to spend the holiday with her dysfunctional family.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

36. Beyond the Call (1996)

Beyond the Call, released in 1996, is a gripping drama film directed by Tony Bill and written by Doug Magee. Set in the aftermath of the Vietnam War, the story revolves around Russell Gates, a Vietnam veteran who is wrongfully convicted of shooting a police officer.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

37. Mother Night (1996)

Mother Night” is a compelling, thought-provoking drama from 1996 that follows the life of an American spy who finds himself ensnared in deep personal and political turmoil. Set against the backdrop of World War II, the story revolves around an American spy who, forced to work as a Nazi propagandist, becomes ensnared in a dark role that he can never escape or reveal.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

38. The Climb (1997)

In “The Climb, “ a tale that takes us on a dramatic journey, the young neighbor kid Danny finds himself enchanted by the stories of the crusty old civic engineer, Chuck. Chuck has a treasure trove of memories that he recounts with an irreverent wit, a distinct and humorous style of storytelling that leaves an indelible mark on the listener’s imagination. Chuck’s tales are not only entertaining but also serve as lessons for the young Danny, who learns valuable morals and life lessons from each one.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

39. Song of Hiawatha (1997)

Song of Hiawatha, “ set in the late 1800s, follows the journey of Ojibwa Chief Hiawatha, a legendary leader chosen by the great spirit to guide his people. With breathtaking cinematography and powerful performances, this adventure-drama transports viewers to the heart of the American frontier. Based on the epic poem by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, the film showcases the strength and wisdom of the Native American community as they navigate the challenges of their time.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

40. L.A. Confidential (1997)

In the heart of 1950s Los Angeles, corruption runs rampant, and three unlikely LA detectives are on a thrilling and dangerous mission to uncover the truth behind a series of brutal murders. Straight-laced Exley, brutal Vincennes, and sleazy White form an unorthodox trio who will stop at nothing to expose the city’s darkest secrets.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

41. Bad Manners (1997)

Bad Manners” (1997) is a comedic drama that explores the complexities of jealousy, suspicion, and trust within a seemingly ordinary family unit. Academics Wes and Nancy, portrayed by David Strathairn and Bonnie Bedelia, are a seemingly picture-perfect couple. Their world turns upside-down when Nancy’s long-lost lover, Matt, arrives with his current girlfriend, Kim. Matt is a talented musician and Kim, an intelligent computer specialist.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

42. Evidence of Blood (1998)

Evidence of Blood”, a gripping 1998 release, follows the journey of a Pulitzer Prize-winning author. His life takes a dramatic turn when he returns to his hometown, only to become entangled in a 40-year-old cold case. The murder of a teenager haunts him, stirring his vivid memory to confront the grisly past.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

43. With Friends Like These (1998)

With Friends Like These” is a 1998 comedy film that follows four close-knit actors as they compete to secure a significant role in a Martin Scorsese mob film. The talented cast, starring Robert Costanzo, David Strathairn, and Adam Arkin, portray eccentric individuals who are pitted against each other for the coveted part. Philip Frank Messina takes the helm as both director and writer, bringing his unique vision to life on screen in the realm of independent cinema.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

44. The Giraffe (1998)

The Giraffe” (Meschugge) is a captivating 1998 thriller film directed by Dani Levy and Maria Schrader. Centered around the dynamic between Lena Katz, a Jewish German woman, and David Fish, a Jewish American man living in New York, the movie takes a dark turn when Lena’s mother arrives from Germany, only to find an almost-dead woman on the hotel floor, later identified as David’s mother.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

45. Simon Birch (1998)

In the heartwarming family drama “Simon Birch”, a young boy named Simon (played by Joseph Mazzello) is born with stunted growth, which leads him to believe he was created for a significant purpose. Surrounded by the love and support of his friends, Simon embarks on a journey of self-discovery and acceptance.

46. A Midsummer Night’s Dream (1999)

A Midsummer Night’s Dream” (1999) is a witty and enchanting adaptation of Shakespeare’s beloved comedy. Directed by Michael Hoffman and written by both Shakespeare and Hoffman, this film brings the timeless story of love, mischief, and magic to life with unforgettable flair. Set in a city where love is as complicated as the law, the story follows the intertwining lives of four lovers and their encounters with feuding fairy royalty. As the young couples navigate their way through the tangled web of their own emotions, they stumble upon a love potion that brings them closer than they ever anticipated.

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

47. A Good Baby (1999)

A Good Baby” is a heart-wrenching drama that unfolds in the quiet back roads of North Carolina. When a young loner named Paul discovers an abandoned baby, an unexpected bond between the child and him begins to form. As he embarks on a journey to find the baby’s parents, he is also compelled to address his own deep-rooted isolation.

48. Limbo (1999)

In the economically devastated town of Limbo, Alaska, a troubled fisherman named Ross is entangled in a dangerous web of crime. Struggling with his past and trying to redeem himself, he starts dating a woman named Vicki, who has a young daughter disapproving of his presence. Tragedy strikes when Ross’s shady brother is brutally murdered.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

49. A Map of the World (1999)

A Map of the World is a powerful drama film that tells the tale of a woman’s life unraveling after she is falsely accused of causing an accident on her land. The movie, released in 1999, stars acclaimed actors Sigourney Weaver and Julianne Moore, with a supporting cast including Dara Perlmutter. Directed by Scott Elliott and written by Jane Hamilton, Peter Hedges, and Polly Platt, this gripping narrative unfolds against the backdrop of a dairy farm in Wisconsin.

50. Freedom Song (2000)

Freedom Song” is a deeply moving and thought-provoking drama film that takes us back to the tumultuous period of the 1960s in Mississippi, a time when racial segregation and injustice were rampant. The story revolves around a young man’s courageous journey during this pivotal era.

51. Harrison’s Flowers (2000)

Harrison’s Flowers is a dramatic romance and war film that transports viewers to the treacherous terrain of war-torn Yugoslavia. When a renowned Newsweek photojournalist mysteriously vanishes in the midst of the Croatian War of Independence, his anguished wife embarks on a perilous journey to Europe in search of answers. Directed by Élie Chouraqui and starring Andie MacDowell, Elias Koteas, and Scott Anton, this gripping tale unfolds against the backdrop of the Battle of Vukovar.

52. Relative Evil (2001)

In “Relative Evil, “ also known as “Ball in the House, “ a troubled 17-year-old named Jack navigates life after drug rehab. Struggling to find his place, he becomes entangled in a twisted web of deceit when he discovers his family has an unusual insurance policy. As Jack tries to piece together the truth, he’s forced to out-smart those around him.

53. Speakeasy (2002)

Experience a heartfelt and thought-provoking journey with “Speakeasy, “ a 2002 drama directed by Brendan Murphy. Boasting an impressive ensemble of David Strathairn, Nicky Katt, and Stacy Edwards, this 1h 26 min film is a touching tale of friendship, discovery, and the power of music.

54. Blue Car (2002)

Blue Car” is a captivating drama film that tells the story of a young woman’s struggle with family issues and her journey towards self-discovery. Directed by Karen Moncrieff, the movie follows a troubled adolescent who finds solace and encouragement from an unexpected source — her high school English teacher.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

55. Lathe of Heaven (2002)

Step into the world of “Lathe of Heaven, “ a mind-bending science fiction film released in 2002. Set in a dystopian future, our protagonist, George Orr, discovers he has an extraordinary ability to alter reality through his dreams. When his psychiatrist, Dr. Hassan, comes across this seemingly impossible claim, he decides to exploit George’s gift to create a utopia. But as the lines between perception and reality blur, the consequences of George’s dream world are not what he imagined.

56. Master Spy: The Robert Hanssen Story (2002)

Based on the true story of the FBI’s relentless pursuit to uncover a Soviet mole within their ranks, Master Spy: The Robert Hanssen Story (2002) unfolds as a gripping drama. Robert Hanssen, a top FBI agent, is revealed to be the elusive mole, creating a thrilling cat-and-mouse game that spans years. As the FBI frantically searches for the traitor among them, Hanssen’s duplicitous nature and personal life play a crucial role in the film’s exploration.

57. Los Angeles Plays Itself (2003)

Los Angeles Plays Itself” is a fascinating documentary that explores the city of Los Angeles through its various cinematic portrayals. Directed by Thom Andersen and featuring interviews with urban theorists, architects, and film critics, the film delves into the urban setting of Hollywood, California, and how it has been influenced by popular culture and philosophy.

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

58. Twisted (2004)

In the riveting crime thriller “Twisted, “ Jessica, a dedicated police officer, finds herself entangled in a chilling web of murder as the people from her past start to turn up dead. Haunted by the memory of her father, who brutally killed her mother, Jessica faces the unsettling reality that she may be next. As she frantically investigates the series of gruesome killings linked to her former lovers, the line between truth and fiction begins to blur.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

59. Good Night, and Good Luck. (2005)

In the late 1950s, during the height of the Red Scare, esteemed broadcast journalist Edward R. Murrow (David Strathairn) becomes determined to expose the corruption and abuse of power at the hands of Senator Joseph McCarthy (Patricia Clarkson). This gripping drama, directed by George Clooney and co-written with Grant Heslov, showcases Murrow’s unwavering commitment to the truth and his relentless pursuit of justice.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

60. The Notorious Bettie Page (2005)

The Notorious Bettie Page” is a gripping biographical drama that delves into the life of Bettie Page, a trailblazing figure of the 1950s. This riveting film portrays the journey of a woman who, as a pin-up model and sex icon, became a target of a Senate investigation due to her scandalous bondage photos.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

61. Missing in America (2005)

Missing in America”, a gripping drama film released in 2005, follows the life of Jake, a Vietnam War veteran who’s lived in isolation in the woods for years, hiding from the horrors of his past. With a gruff exterior and a solitary existence, Jake’s life takes an unexpected turn when an enterprising young girl infiltrates his routine, ultimately shaking the foundations of his heart and forcing him to confront the ghosts of his past.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

62. Steel Toes (2006)

In the 2006 film “Steel Toes, “ Academy Award-nominee David Strathairn stars as a Jewish humanist and lawyer who finds himself court-appointed to defend a Neo-Nazi Skinhead accused of a racially-motivated murder. This intense crime drama showcases the complex moral dilemmas that arise when representation must be given to those whose beliefs conflict with one’s own.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

63. The Sensation of Sight (2006)

Immerse yourself in the poignant journey of “The Sensation of Sight, “ a captivating drama that intertwines the themes of love, loss, and the longing for deeper meaning. Filmed in 2006 and directed by Aaron J. Wiederspahn, this compelling tale follows the story of Finn, an introspective English teacher who finds himself on the brink of a mid-life crisis after a recent tragedy. As he sets out on a peculiar path selling encyclopedias door-to-door throughout his quaint town, Finn is forced to confront the harsh realities of life and navigate the intricate web of relationships that surround him.
